Question: Why did you compose this treatise?
Answer: In order to explain the views and tendencies spoken of in the sutras and to make people know how to eliminate them.
Why is this so?
In the cycle of birth and death, one gives rise to great attachment and brings about great misfortune.
There is nothing that relies on and grasps more than views and tendencies.
These are explained in detail in the five topics and sections on cognition in the Abhidharma-mahÄvibhÄá¹£Ä-Å›Ästra.
Those who have the view that there is no giving, no love, no sacrifice, no good or bad conduct,
this is the wrong view that denies causation, eliminated by the path of seeing the truth of the origin of suffering.
No giving, etc. is explained above.
This wrong view shows its intrinsic nature.
Eliminated by the path of seeing the truth of the origin of suffering shows its antidote.
Namely, the acceptance and knowledge of the truth of the origin of suffering that have already arisen, and the improper investigation and improper discrimination regarding it.
The inverted views, unequal grasping, are then permanently eliminated and extinguished.
Moreover, this view arises based on the place of accumulation, so when one sees the accumulation, it is eliminated.
Like dew on grass, when the sun comes out, it dries up.
This is also like that. The denial of the fruits of good and evil actions is the wrong view that denies the fruits, which is eliminated by seeing suffering.
This wrong view reveals its own nature.
Eliminated by seeing suffering reveals its antidote.
That is, when the acceptance and knowledge of the truth of suffering have already arisen,
the improper investigation, improper discrimination, inverted views, and unequal grasping are then permanently eliminated and extinguished.
Moreover, this view arises based on the place of suffering, so when one sees suffering, it is eliminated.
Like dew on grass, when the sun comes out, it dries up.
This is also like that.
However, this only explains its own nature and antidote.
It does not explain its origination.
What is its origination?
Venerable Vasumitra said:
There are non-Buddhists who directly perceive that in the world, those who kill have long lives, while those who abstain from killing have short lives.
Those who steal have abundant wealth, while those who abstain from stealing lack wealth.
Those who are stingy are rich, while those who practice generosity are poor.
Those who harm others are healthy and happy,
while those who do not harm others suffer from many illnesses.
Having seen such contradictory things, they think:
There is no giving, no loving-kindness, up to no good or bad actions and their results.
If there were, then all those who kill would have short lives,
up to those who do not harm others would be healthy and happy.
Since we directly see contradictions, we know that there definitely is no giving, and so on, in detail.
However, those non-Buddhists do not understand well that the results of good and bad actions have far and near,
so they think about what they directly see in an unreasonable way and give rise to this view.
Some say:
Non-Buddhists attain worldly concentration and see a short period of time, not knowing the beginning and end, the distinctions of cause and effect.
They see that those who practice evil can be reborn in the heavens.
Seeing those who do good fall into evil destinies,
they think, There is no giving, no love, and so on.
Some say:
There are non-Buddhists who, without relying on direct perception or concentration,
merely follow the teachings of bad friends and say there is no giving, and so on.

or the wrong view that denies effects, which is eliminated by the path of seeing the truth of suffering.
Question: It is reasonable to say there is no other world because it is not directly perceived.
Why do they say there is no this world, which is directly perceived?
Answer: Those non-Buddhists, blinded by ignorance, deny even what is directly perceived.
One should not blame the ignorant or the blind for falling into pits.
Furthermore, some say:
Those non-Buddhists only deny causes and effects, not the substance of dharmas.
There is no this world means there is no this world as the cause for the other world,
or there is no this world as the effect of the other world.
Those who say there is no other world mean that there is no other world as the cause of this world.
Or that there is no other world as the result of this world.
Those who say there are no spontaneously born sentient beings are certain non-Buddhists who say:
The birth of all sentient beings is all due to present semen and blood, etc.
There are none that are born without a cause, suddenly.
For example, a sprout grows only due to a seed, water, soil, and season. There are none that grow without a cause.
Therefore, there definitely are no spontaneously born sentient beings.
This either denies the karma that produces spontaneous birth,
or it denies the spontaneous birth that is produced.
There are some who say:
Spontaneously born sentient beings refer to the intermediate existence.
Those who say there is no this world or other world deny the existence of birth.
Those who say there are no spontaneously born sentient beings deny the existence of the intermediate existence.
There are certain non-Buddhists who say the intermediate existence does not exist.
They say that one only goes from this world to the other world. There is no third world that can be obtained.
This either denies the karma that produces the intermediate existence,
Or they deny the existence of the intermediate state that is to be experienced.
Or they deny that the intermediate state is the cause of the birth state.
Or they deny that the intermediate state is the effect of the death state.
This wrong view reveals their intrinsic nature.
Either eliminated by the view of the origin or eliminated by the view of suffering reveals their antidotes, as explained in detail above.
There is no father, there is no mother is the wrong view that denies causes, eliminated by the view of the origin.
Question: Parents in the world are all directly perceived. Why do they deny their existence?
Answer: Those non-Buddhists are blinded by ignorance, and so on.
Some say:
Those non-Buddhists deny the karma that produces children, not their existence.
They argue that parents do not have children out of love and desire,
but because the conditions of semen and blood come together, that kind of child is born. It is not that parents have the karma to produce children.
Just as worms are born from wet leaves, manure, and so on,
it is not that wet leaves and so on have the karma to produce worms. This is also like that.
Therefore, those non-Buddhists have this verse:
When a man and woman with lustful minds unite, if the woman is in season and not sick,
From this I have my own existence. What does he have to do with me?
Some say:
Those non-Buddhists slander the meaning of parents, but do not slander their essence.
Like worms born from wet leaves and excrement,
leaves and so on are not the father or mother of the worms.
In the same way, they are born from that impurity.
Why then do they alone have the heavy kindness and virtue of parents towards the born?
Therefore, that kind says there are no parents.
This wrong view shows their own nature. The view of the origin of suffering is eliminated. It shows their antidote. It is explained in detail as before.
Here, only their own nature and antidote are explained, but not their origination.
What is their origination?
Venerable Vasumitra said:
When some non-Buddhists see bubbles floating in a heavy rain, they think like this:
Where do these come from? Where do they go when they disappear?
But the water and rain arise suddenly and disappear suddenly.
In the same way, sentient beings are born due to the convergence of conditions.
They die due to the separation of conditions.
They do not come from the previous world to this birth.
Nor do they go from this birth to the next world. Therefore, they definitely say there is no this world and no other world.
Moreover, they see that in the world, parents give birth to children, and water and soil give rise to sprouts. They see that all exist due to the convergence of conditions.
They think, Where will there be sentient beings born by transformation?
Moreover, they see that insects are born from wet leaves and so on, as explained in detail above.
However, those non-Buddhists do not know that sentient beings and insentient beings are different categories, and that sentient beings are born in four ways.
They rely on different conditions. Internal phenomena and external phenomena have different natures of conditions.
Therefore, they improperly contemplate these views based on a few similar events.
There are also those who say:
Those non-Buddhists who attain worldly concentration see that some sentient beings die in the upper realms and other worlds and are reborn here.
Or, having died here, they are reborn in a higher realm or in another world.
They observe this kind of being and do not see where it comes from or where it goes,
so they give rise to the view that there is no this world or other world.
Moreover, because they attain a coarse and shallow concentration, when they observe the past and future worlds, they only see the existence of birth.
They do not see the body of the intermediate state in between because it is subtle.
Because of this, they say there are no sentient beings born through transformation.
Moreover, due to the power of concentration, they observe sentient beings, sometimes their enemies come to be their parents,
or sometimes their wives, children, brothers, sisters come to be their parents.
Up to sometimes from the bodies of various kinds such as camels, donkeys, dogs, etc. they come to be their parents.
And from their parents they become those kinds of forms, so they think like this.
What is definite about this inn?
Because of this, they say there is no father and no mother.
Moreover, there are those who say:
Those non-Buddhists do not rely on direct perception or concentration.
It is only because of following the teachings of evil friends that it is said that there is no such world, and so on.
Those who have this view that there are no arhats in the world,ğŸ”½this is the wrong view that denies the path, which is eliminated by seeing the truth of the path.
This wrong view that denies the path shows its intrinsic nature.
Eliminated by seeing the truth of the path shows its antidote.
That is to say, when the acceptance and knowledge of the truth of the path have already arisen,
the improper investigation, improper discrimination, inverted views, and unequal grasping that exist in relation to that are forever eliminated and extinguished.
Moreover, this view arises in relation to the path, so when the truth of the path is seen, it is eliminated.
Like dew on grass that dries up when the sun comes out,
this is also like that, without proper attainment.
This wrong view that denies cessation denies nirvana, which is eliminated by seeing the truth of cessation.
Proper attainment refers to nirvana, because it is what should be attained by the uncontaminated path.
This wrong view that denies cessation shows its intrinsic nature.
Eliminated by seeing the truth of cessation shows its antidote.
That is to say, when the acceptance and knowledge of the truth of cessation have already arisen,
Regarding those incorrect investigations, incorrect discriminations, inverted views, and unequal graspings, they are forever eliminated and extinguished.
Furthermore, since this view arises in the place of cessation, when cessation is seen, it is eliminated.
Like dew on grass, when the sun comes out, it dries up.
This is also like that. Without correct practice in this world and the next, one then in the present life knows, realizes, and abides in perfect realization.
My births are ended, the holy life has been established, what was to be done has been done, there will be no more of this state of existence.
This is the correct knowledge of this slanderous wrong view, which is eliminated by seeing the path.
Without correct practice in this world and the next means that they deny the four kinds of correct practice.
Then suffering and slow penetration, etc. This is the slander of the path of learning.
The rest is the slander of the path of no-more-learning.
This slanderous wrong view shows their intrinsic nature.
Eliminated by seeing the path shows their antidote, as explained in detail above.
Herein, only their intrinsic nature and antidote are mentioned.
Their origination is not mentioned.
How do they arise?
Venerable Vasumitra said:
There are non-Buddhists who see that arhats have old age, sickness, death, and experience various sufferings.
They consider it the same as other sentient beings and say that there are no arhats in the world.
This is slandering the non-existence of the Dharma of arhats.
Moreover, hearing that in nirvana the faculties are eternally extinguished, they think that it should be suffering.
Again, hearing that in nirvana all activities are extinguished, they think that it should be non-existence.
Seeing that the appearance and food of sages are the same as other sentient beings, they say that they do not have any noble path.
However, those non-Buddhists do not know that the contaminated body of sages is different from the uncontaminated body, and that nirvana is tranquil bliss.
It is neither suffering nor non-existence, so they give rise to such discriminating wrong views.
Some say:
Non-Buddhists who attain mundane concentration are unable to observe and see the noble path and nirvana.
They then say that there are no arhats, and so on.
Some say:
Non-Buddhists do not rely on direct perception or concentration.
But they say that in the world there are no arhats, and so on, only because they follow the teachings of bad friends.
Some say that here it should be explained that the matter of Åšaá¹…kha is the origin of this view and so on.

Those who have this view,
up to the end of life, have a life-force. After death, it is cut off and destroyed, and does not exist.
This great element body of a man,
and so on at length.
This extreme view is included in the view of annihilation.
It is eliminated by seeing suffering.
Here, up to the end of life, one has a life-force. After death, it is cut off and destroyed, and does not exist.
They grasp at the existence of a self, which is called a life-force.
This life-force, up to this birth, is always present as long as one is not dead.
After death, it no longer continues, and is called cut off and destroyed, and does not exist.
This great element body of a man.
The body of a man spoken of by them is also composed of other dharmas, but only the great elements are mentioned because they are coarse and obvious.
When dying, the earth body returns to earth, the water body returns to water, the fire body returns to fire, the wind body returns to wind, and the faculties follow the void.
They say that when sentient beings die, the internal great elements of the body return to external earth and so forth.
Because the faculties have no great elements as their support, they then follow the void and transform.
It is like when a tree falls, the birds fly into the sky.
This is included in the view of eternalism, and is eliminated by seeing suffering.
Because it grasps the self and what belongs to the self as being permanent.
The bier is the fifth.
It is a bier half the size of four cubits, carried by four people.
It is used to send the corpse.
Therefore it is said that the bier is the fifth.
Carrying the corpse to the charnel ground.
The place where the body is given away or burned is called the charnel ground.
The one who has not yet been burned can be known.
It refers to as long as it has not yet been burned, the distinctions can be seen.
After being burned, it becomes ashes.

It refers to if it has been burned, it then becomes ashes.

If it refers to burning contaminated karma, this is wrong view that denies causes, eliminated by seeing the truth of the origin of suffering.
If it refers to burning uncontaminated karma, this is wrong view that denies the path, eliminated by seeing the truth of the path.
Fools praise giving, the wise praise receiving.
Fools refer to those without wisdom or those with evil wisdom.
The wise refer to those with wisdom and good wisdom.
The non-Buddhists say that fools praise practicing giving.
The wise praise receiving the given gifts.
However, the Buddha, pratyekabuddhas, and noble disciples, who are the wise, all praise practicing giving.
They deny this, calling it foolish.
This is denying the Dharma that leads to becoming a wise one.
This is wrong view that denies the path.
It is eliminated by seeing the truth of the path.
All those who argue that everything is empty and false speech, up to the existence of fools and wise ones in life, but after death they are cut off and destroyed, and do not exist,
Those who speak of the existence of the afterlife are called proponents of existence.
They all slander it as empty and false speech.
They say that even while alive, there are fools and sages, but after death, everything is cut off and destroyed, and there is nothing.
However, the Buddha, pratyekabuddhas, and the disciples of the sages speak of the existence of the afterlife.
They deny it as false.
This is slandering the Dharma of those who speak true words.
This is wrong view that slanders the path.
It is to be eliminated by the path of seeing.
This extreme view is included in the view of annihilation.
This shows their intrinsic nature.
Although there are other wrong views here,ğŸ”½but only the annihilation and non-existence are shown.

It is to be eliminated by seeing suffering.
This shows their antidote, which is explained in detail as before.
This only explains their intrinsic nature and antidote, but not their origination.

Venerable Vasumitra said:
There are some non-Buddhists who do not remember the past and do not see the future.
Counting all sentient beings, they are born in this way, and death is the last.
Moreover, for those who die, there is no return, so it is said that even those who are alive have life.
After death, it is cut off and destroyed, and there is none.
It is like grass and trees, without an afterlife.
Some say.
Non-Buddhists attain worldly concentration.
Some sentient beings die here and are reborn in higher realms and other worlds.
They observe this kind and do not know where they go, so they say.
Even those who are alive have life.

Non-Buddhists, without relying on other matters, simply due to evil friends' wrong teachings, say this.
Even those who are alive have life, it is explained in detail.

Venerable Vasumitra said:
There are non-Buddhists who directly see in the world:
Some who dwell in secluded places give rise to defilements,
while some who live in cities do not give rise to defilements.
They then think: Without causes and conditions, sentient beings become defiled.
Without causes and conditions, sentient beings become defiled.
If there were [causes and conditions], then those who dwell in secluded places should not give rise to defilements,
while those who live in cities should all give rise to defilements, contradicting what is directly seen.
Therefore, it is certain that there are no causes and conditions, and so on, explained in detail.
However, sentient beings become defiled due to three things:
First, due to the power of causes,
second, due to the power of practice,
and third, due to the power of objects.
Those who dwell in secluded places, although without objects, give rise to various defilements due to the power of causes and the power of practice.
Although those who dwell in cities and towns have causes and objects,
because they lack the power of practice, they do not give rise to defilements.
They are unable to penetrate this matter and give rise to this view, saying there is no cause and no condition, and so on.
Some say:
Because non-Buddhists attain coarse and shallow worldly concentration,
they observe sentient beings giving rise to various defilements,
but do not see the distinctions in causes and conditions.
They then give rise to this view, saying there is no cause and no condition, and so on.
Some say:
Non-Buddhists do not arise from direct perception or concentration,
but arise from evil friends, giving rise to this view that there is no cause and no condition that purifies sentient beings.
Without cause and without condition, sentient beings are purified.
This is the wrong view that denies the path, which is eliminated by the path of seeing.
The wrong view that denies the path shows its intrinsic nature.
Eliminated by the path of seeing shows its antidote, as explained in detail above.
What is its origin?
Venerable Vasumitra said:
There are non-Buddhists who observe that some people living in cities attain purity,
while some living in secluded places do not attain purity.
They then think: There are no causes and conditions that can make sentient beings pure.
Purity of sentient beings is not due to causes and conditions.
If there were, then all those living in secluded places would be pure,
while all those living in cities would be impure.
This is clearly contradictory.
Therefore, it is certain that there are no causes and conditions... and so on, speaking extensively.
However, sentient beings attain purity due to three things:
First, the power of causes;
Second, the power of practice;
Third, the power of conditions.
Those living in secluded places, although having causes and conditions, may not attain purity due to lacking practice.
Those living in cities, although lacking conditions, may attain purity due to the power of causes and practice.
They are unable to understand this matter and thus give rise to this view.
There are no causes and conditions... and so on, speaking extensively.
Some say:
Because non-Buddhists attain coarse and shallow worldly concentrations,
they see sentient beings attaining purity but do not see the causes and conditions for their attainment of purity.
They then give rise to the view that there are no causes and no conditions, and so on.
